facts.text: Petition No. 103 of 1958 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 103 of 1958. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on December 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: C. K. Achuthan filed petition under Article 32 claiming to have held a contract for supply of milk and other articles for 1958-1959.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution by one C. K. Achuthan, who claims to have held a companytract for the supply of milk and other articles of diet for the year 1958-1959

facts.text: Contract for supply of milk cancelled by District Medical Officer, second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: but whose companytract for supply of milk is said to have been cancelled by the District Medical Officer  second respondent herein .

facts.text: Contract for supply of milk given to third respondent, Co-operative Milk Supplies Society, Cannanore.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract for the. supply of milk has number been given to the third respondent, the Co-operative Milk Supplies Society, Cannanore.

facts.text: Petitioner held contracts for supply of milk to Government Hospital at Cannanore, Kerala State since 1946.

anchor.surface_text: From the petition, it appears that the petitioner held companytracts for the supply of milk to the Government Hospital at Cannanore  Kerala State  ever since 1946,

facts.text: Petitioner's brother held similar contracts from 1936.

anchor.surface_text: and that previous to this, his brother in the same business held similar companytracts from 1936.

facts.text: In 1957, uniform procedure for fixing contracts adopted and conditions for tenders laid down by notification.

anchor.surface_text: In 1957, a uniform procedure for fixing up companytracts was adopted, and by a numberification, companyditions for acceptance of tender were laid down.

facts.text: Petitioner and third respondent submitted tenders.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner as well as the third respondent submitted their respective tenders,

facts.text: Tenders opened by Superintendent of the Hospital in presence of interested parties.

anchor.surface_text: which were to be opened by the Superintendent of the Hospital in the presence of interested parties.

facts.text: On January 20, 1958, petitioner's tender for supply of milk accepted and third respondent's rejected.

anchor.surface_text: On January 20, 1958, the tenders which were submitted were scrutinised and the tender of the petitioner for the supply of milk was accepted and that of the third respondent rejected.

facts.text: Superintendent (respondent No. 2) communicated reasons to Director of Public Health for accepting petitioner's tender and rejecting third respondent's.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Superintendent  respondent No. 2  companymunicated to the Director of Public Health, her reasons for accepting the tender of the petitioner and number accepting that of the third respondent.

facts.text: Correspondence ensued between Director of Health Services and second respondent, resulting in cancellation of petitioner's contract.

anchor.surface_text: Certain companyrespondence then ensued between the Director of Health Services and the second respondent, as a result of which the petitioner was informed that the companytract for the supply of milk given to him was cancelled.

facts.text: Petitioner informed of Government policy to give contracts for supply to medical institutions in Cannanore District to Co-operative Milk Supplies Union on prices fixed by Revenue Department.

anchor.surface_text: He was informed that it was the policy of Government that in the matter of supply to Government medical institutions in Cannanore District the Co-operative Milk Supplies Union was to be given companytracts on the basis of prices fixed by the Revenue Department.

facts.text: Further correspondence; instructed to act under Clause 20 of tender conditions and give one month's notice before cancellation.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some more companyrespondence between the Director of Health Services and the second respondent ensued, and it was pointed out to the second respondent that action should have been taken under Cl. 20 of the companyditions of the tender and the companytract only cancelled after giving a months numberice to the petitioner.

facts.text: Second respondent issued notice under Clause 20 and cancelled the contract after notice period.

anchor.surface_text: In furtherance of these instructions, the second respondent issued a numberice in terms of Cl. 20 of the tender, and cancelled the companytract after the numberice period.

facts.text: Petitioner previously filed O. P. No. 201 of 1958 under Article 226 in Kerala High Court, rejected by Raman Nayar, J. on June 6, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that previous to this, the petitioner had applied under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Kerala, but his petition  O. P. No. 201 of 1958  was rejected by Raman Nayar, J., on June 6, 1958.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal A. S. No. 354 of 1958 dismissed by Koshi, C. J. and Vaidialingam, J. on July 7, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: A Letters Patent Appeal was also dismissed by Koshi, C. J., and Vaidialingam, J.  A. S. No. 354 of 1958 decided on July 7, 1958 .

facts.text: Kerala High Court held matter is breach of contract, remedy is civil suit, not under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the present matter was numbermore than a breach, if any, of the companytract by the State Government, and that the appropriate remedy was to file a civil suit and number to proceed under Art. 226.

facts.text: No special leave to appeal sought from Supreme Court against High Court orders.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that -no special leave to appeal was sought from this Court against the above orders,

Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights. T. Paikeday and Ganpat Rai, for the petitioner. Sardar Bahadur, for respondent No. 1. R. Krishna Pillai, for respondent No. 3. 1958. December 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is a petition under Art. 32

Art. 32 of the Constitution by one C. K. Achuthan, who claims to have held a contract for the supply of milk and other articles of diet for the year 1958-1959 but whose contract for supply of milk is said to have been cancelled by the District Medical Officer  second respondent herein .

arguments.claim: No absolute right to continued possession of government contract due to Cl. 20 termination clause

anchor.surface_text: But even if he held the contract, the petitioner did not acquire an absolute right to be continued in that contract, because power was reserved by the Government under Cl. 20 to terminate the contract after giving a months notice.

holdings.text: None of Articles 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g) and 31 of the Constitution can be made applicable to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, none of these Articles can be made applicable to the facts of the present case. No doubt, the petitioner claims to have succeeded in obtaining the contract from the Government,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's claims under these articles do not fit the facts as contract cancellation does not infringe fundamental rights.

holdings.text: The petitioner did not acquire an absolute right to be continued in the contract because power was reserved under Clause 20 to terminate after one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: But even if he held the contract, the petitioner did not acquire an absolute right to be continued in that contract, because power was reserved by the Government under Cl. 20 to terminate the contract after giving a months notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract terms explicitly reserve government's power to terminate, preventing absolute right.

holdings.text: Adjudication of whether the power under Clause 20 was exercised regularly or legally is for ordinary Civil Courts.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the exercise of that power in the present case was regular or legal, is not a matter on which we are called upon to pronounce, because adjudication of such dispute can appropriately take place only before the ordinary Civil Courts,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract disputes require evidence and are suited for civil courts, not writ jurisdiction.

holdings.text: There is no discrimination under Article 14 because the Government can choose a contractor to its liking like a private party.

anchor.surface_text: There is nodiscrimination, because it is perfectly open to the Government, even as it is to a private party, to choose a person to their liking, to fulfill contracts which they wish to be performed. When one person is chosen rather than another,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Choice of contractor is discretionary; no equality right violated in selection.

holdings.text: The aggrieved party cannot claim protection of Article 14 in the government's choice of contractor.

anchor.surface_text: the aggrieved party cannot claim the protection of Art. 14, because the choice of the person to fulfill a particular contract must be left to the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 14 does not constrain government's contractual discretion.

holdings.text: Breach of government contract does not deprive the right under Article 19(1)(g) to carry on trade or business.

anchor.surface_text: The breach of the contract, if any, may entitle the person aggrieved to sue for damages or in appropriate cases, even specific performance, but he cannot complain that there has been a deprivation of the right to practise any profession or to carry on any occupation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract breach gives civil remedies, not fundamental right violation.

holdings.text: Article 31 cannot be invoked to prevent cancellation of a contract under its own terms.

anchor.surface_text: Nor has it been shown how Art. 31 of the Constitution may be invoked to prevent cancellation of a contract in exercise of powers conferred by one of the terms of the contract itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No deprivation of property shown where contract allows termination.

holdings.text: Article 16(1) is confined to employment in service by the State, not to contractors supplying goods.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and contextual interpretation limits Art.16(1) to service/employment, excluding supply contracts; petitioner is contractor, not servant.

holdings.text: Article 16(1) of the Constitution is not attracted to the facts of the case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner sells/supplies goods, not employed as servant.

holdings.text: The petition under Article 32 is wholly misconceived; no fundamental right is involved.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute is contractual breach, not fundamental rights infringement; remedy lies in civil court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved. At best, it is a right to take the matter to the Civil Court, if so advised, and to claim damages for breach of companytract, if any.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Art. 32 held wholly misconceived as no fundamental right involved; remedy lies in civil court for breach of contract
directions: Petitioner at liberty to take the matter to the Civil Court, if so advised, and claim damages for breach of contract, if any

In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved. At best, it is a right to take the matter to the Civil Court, if so advised, and to claim damages for breach of companytract, if any.
Nor has it been shown how Art. 31 of the Constitution may be invoked to prevent cancellation of a contract in exercise of powers conferred by one of the terms of the contract itself.

In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved. At best, it is a right to take the matter to the Civil Court, if so advised, and to claim damages for breach of companytract, if any.
